BE

strong results for peer Home depot and Lowe.

BE

Despite the strong Q3 results; weak trading
trends witnessed in the weeks post the Q3 growth could weigh negatively on the stock price
today. We will get more clarity on these trends at the conference call today. However, we
would highlight that margin expansion in the, the group’s largest business, is very positive
and, also, the valuation is still cheap at 14.2x on 2017e CY earnings – an 18% discount to US distributor peers. The 2017e div yield is 2.8% with a 40% payout ratio and still some left for buybacks/bolt-on acquisition.

BE

And, um, how about Oddo for a change.

11:16 am
BE

By region, we note:
 A good performance from the US with organic growth of 5%, of which -2.3% price effect
reflecting a very good performance from volumes. The margin rose by 70bp (+20bp over
the first nine months).
 The performance from the UK stabilised with a decline of just 0.4% in LFL sales
(-2.9% in Q2) and of -17bp for the margin (-48bp over the first nine months). At a time when
the renovation market remains sluggish, the group is pursuing its strategic review which
should be completed in August.
 Nordic countries turned in a disappointing performance with a 2.6% decline in LFL sales
(+1.8% over the first nine months) and -100bp on the margin. The group indicated that it
had been penalised by unfavourable weather conditions and the decline in tax incentives.

PM

Oddo -- that is a change

BE

Group indicated that since the end of the quarter (30 April), organic growth has
averaged 1%. It confirmed, moreover, that it is forecasting a trading profit in line with the
consensus expectations at constant currency (i.e. £ 925m vs Oddo's estimate of £ 930m).
In light of this publication and ahead of this morning's 9.00 a.m. (CET) conference call, we
confirm our Neutral recommendation with a target price of 4,100p. Wolseley is trading at
2016e EV/EBIT (restated) of 11.8x in line with the median of peer groups, which in our view
is still insufficiently attractive given: i/ the slowdown in growth and ii/ limited potential for
asset rotation (acquisitions limited to £ 23m in Q3).

11:17 am
BE

And Davy, for less of a change.

BE

Wolseley has announced fiscal Q3 trading profits that are
comfortably better than expected. As has been the case for a
long time, the 18% year-on-year gain in profit was all due to
another super performance by the US business. However, the
revelation that group organic revenue growth has slowed to
1% since the start of May will raise eyebrows. While there is
likely to be enough in the bag to meet current year
expectations there will be concerns over forecasts for the year
to end-July 2017. This may weigh on the stock which has done
well year-to-date (up almost 10%) and which already looked to
be trading on a relatively full rating.

11:20 am
BE

Here's the full hokum in the press release.

BE

IRVING, Texas, Oct. 16, 2015 PRNewswire -- Hanson Building Products has changed its name to Forterra following the recent sale of the company. The new name reflects the company's strength, its focus on the future, and its continued dedication to providing premier products and services. The name Forterra captures the company's essence and purpose – giving form (For-) to the earth (-terra).

BE

... "captures the company's essence and purpose" by changing the name to something that sounds like a pre-trials biotech.

11:21 am
PM

omg smile

BE

Lone Star then floated it April 2016, which is a spectacularly quick turnaround.

BE

Though it seems HeidelbergCement appears to still own the name Hanson, judging by the risk factors in the prospectus.

11:21 am
BE

The Group’s rebranding efforts could have a material adverse effect on the Group Prior to the Lone Star Acquisition, the Group operated as a wholly owned business of the HeidelbergCement Group and marketed the Group’s products primarily using the “Hanson” brand name and logo. Following completion of the Lone Star Acquisition, each member of the Group and the Forterra NA Group was required to discontinue their use of “Hanson” and related names. On 5 October 2015, the Group announced that it was rebranding the Group’s business under the “Forterra” name and began using the “Forterra” name and logo, which represented a change from the underlying brand under which the Group previously conducted business and sold many of its products.
The rebranding may impact the Group’s future operating results. The Group may lose customers if they do not respond favourably to the new brand or fail to recognise the new brand as a continuation of the Group’s prior business. This is particularly the case in respect of the Group’s customers who acquire the Group’s products at builders’ merchants and have no direct relationship with the Group. The Directors believe that the Group’s association with the “Hanson” name and with the HeidelbergCement Group at times provided it with preferred status among the Group’s customers, suppliers, other contracting parties and other persons due to its recognised brand, perceived high quality products and services and strong capital base and financial strength. The Group may therefore lose potential new customers who choose not to explore the Group’s product offerings since the Group is no longer branded with the more familiar “Hanson” name. The rebranding may also affect the Group’s ability to recruit qualified personnel.

BE

So as far as I can see, there's nothing to stop Heidelberg making Fletton bricks and selling them under the name Hanson.

BE

Which'd be fun, for fans of bricks.

11:22 am
BE

Speaking of fans of bricks, the brokers who floated this thing have their restrictions off this morning and they're all buyers.

PM

BE

Which, having dumped it on investors at 180p, shouldn't really be a surprise.

11:23 am
BE

Credit Suisse was joint coordinator and bookrunner.

BE

Initiate coverage with an Outperform rating and 204p Price Target: We see Forterra as well placed to benefit from the ongoing favourable growth in the wider UK residential market that we believe will persist for the foreseeable future. We also view the UK brick market as rational, with favourable implications for industry pricing and utilization rates. The most significant driver of our positive investment thesis is, however, the attractive valuation. In particular, we highlight the free cash flow yield as compelling.
Cyclical Tailwinds and Rational Market: We expect continued favourable demand growth patterns of +5% and +4% in the UK residential market in 2016 and 2017, respectively. We see the trend in government policy to stimulate more housebuilding as a clear positive for brick and block producers. The Great Britain (GB) brick market is highly consolidated, with the three largest players controlling c90% of capacity. The industry acted rationally in the downturn with all three of the large operators closing capacity, with GB capacity reduced by c23%. Furthermore, aspirations for commissioning new capacity are limited. We forecast total GB capacity growth of only c12% by 2020 and, as such, we see industry utilisation rates remaining tight. Industry pricing has also been resilient with only two years of contraction in the past 11 years.
Solid Growth: We forecast sales growth of 8% and 7% in the next two years, of which 6% and 5% is organic. We forecast EBITDA growth of 4% and 12% in 2016/17, with cash flow growth driving deleveraging with year-end Net Debt/EBITDA at 1.9x 2016F falling to 1.3x 2017F.
Catalysts: H1 results on 7 September. The EU referendum on 23 June is also a potential risk to overall UK construction demand, but we believe such concerns are already reflected in Forterra's valuation.
Attractive Valuation: On our 2016 forecasts Forterra trades on 6.7x EV/EBITDA and 7.4x PE. We see cash flow dynamics as compelling with a FCF yield of 16% in 2017F (2016F at 9% reported, or 12% excluding Exceptional). The current implied dividend yield in 2016F stands at c5% (c4% pro-rata), rising to c6% in 2017F.

BE

Citi was bookrunner.

11:23 am
BE

We initiate coverage of Forterra with a Buy/High Risk rating, TP of £2.44 (ETR +47%)
Forterra (formerly Hanson Building Products UK) is a leading producer of bricks, blocks and bespoke products in the UK. The UK bricks market is highly consolidated (top 4 control c.90% of the market) with strong barriers to entry, limited import risks and tight domestic supply. In this backdrop, we believe Forterra is well positioned to benefit from positive trends in the UK housing market with its leading position in bricks & blocks and sole supply of premium priced ‘London Brick’. We estimate 3 year EBI T CAGR (2015-18E) of +7.2%.
Growing end-markets, supported by positive macro
We believe Forterra stands to benefit from several positive drivers to the UK housing market: 1) UK housing completions are rising but remain well below historic levels; 2) structural housing shortage underpinned by positive demographics; 3) non-flat housing starts are an increasing proportion of all housing starts, with positive implications for brick volumes; 4) macro influences remain favourable with low interest rates, rising house prices, high employment, rising wage inflation; and 5) the UK Government is pursuing a supportive housing policy.
Forterra growth levers
We believe Forterra’s experienced management team is well positioned to exploit growth in this market through 1) near term de-bottlenecking, adding 8% brick capacity (c.45m bricks pa – incl. c.19m completed in Jan 16), with limited incremental capital investment; 2) medium term capacity expansion, adding 100m brick capacity (greater than 18%) from new facility investment; 3) we also expect new capacity to improve operating efficiency and increase margins.
Current valuation pricing in significant downside risks
Forterra currently trades on a 2017E EV/EBITDA of c.6 times, c.24% discount to its comparable peer Ibstock and c.35% discount to the wider building product sector, which looks relatively undemanding in our view. Our target price of £2.44 implies a multiple of 7.8 times on 2017E EBITDA, implying an ETR of +47%

BE

11:25 am
BE

This report provides the first comprehensive overview of the GB brick industry,
containing detailed analysis of demand-supply, profitability and cash flow,
which strongly supports scope for upside to current valuations. We expect the
GB brick industry to attract increasing investor interest following the public
listing of the two largest players in this heavily consolidated market since Oct-
15 (Ibstock & Forterra, together greater than 70% market share). We see cash flow
generation and cash returns to shareholders as a key theme in the sector.
Initiating Forterra & Ibstock on BUY.

BE

Over 90% of demand for GB bricks is driven by residential construction, and
most of this from new build. We forecast a steady increase in new home
volumes in coming years to address GB’s mounting housing deficit, whilst a
mix towards larger homes which consume more bricks is likely to provide
further support to brick demand. Although we do not expect the government
target of 200k new homes pa in England by 2020 to be met, if it were, we
believe it could drive 7-12% upside pa to current brick demand forecasts.

PM

You really are providing a delight for brick lovers, Bryce

11:26 am
BE

We forecast industry players to benefit from 5.6% demand CAGR to 2020,
reflecting enhanced growth over 2016/17 as key customers complete de-
stocking and domestically-produced bricks replace imports, before normalising
over 2018-20. Versus this, capacity is expected to grow 1.9% pa to 2020 due
to the rational nature of the three largest players in this heavily consolidated
market, but also reflecting long lead times and high barriers to entry for new
entrants. Given the tight supply-demand balance, we expect industry capacity
utilisation to sustain at greater than 90% from 2017 onwards. High capacity utilisation
aids low to mid-single digit price growth forecasts pa, although inflation has
been present at significantly lower utilisation rates historically due to players’
recognition of the price inelasticity of brick demand.

BE

Duopoly with more than 70% market share. I find that interesting .....

BE

eflecting a double-digit operating margin and maintenance capex needs
below depreciation, we see the GB brick industry as a strong free cash flow
generator to 2020 (greater than 15% FCF/sales pa from 2017 onwards). Even after
significant growth capex, we expect the industry will generate sufficient cash
to rapidly pay down debt (DB forecasts average industry net debt of zero by
2020) and to comfortably cover targeted dividend payouts. Barring major
acquisitions, we believe key players could have headroom to return additional
cash equivalent to ≥17% of market cap by 2020.

11:27 am
BE

With the stocks trading at a c.30% discount to construction peers and our positive
sector outlook, we initiate Forterra & Ibstock on BUY. Target prices are derived
from P/E multiples to 2017E EPS. However, DCF analysis suggests considerable
upside with stocks appearing to be pricing in up to 50% margin decline longer
term, which we see as too conservative given industry structure. Forterra is our top
pick given its value advantage (6.5x 2017E P/E). Key risks for the GB brick industry
include UK slowdown/ EU referendum, cost inflation, switch to brick alternatives.

BE

Initiating on BUY: Forterra (TP 250p; 47% upside)/ Ibstock (TP 222p; 9% upside)

Reiterate our Outperform rating and £50 price target: We publish our
updated Shire Baxalta model ahead of the expected deal closing on June 3.
We see 5% EPS accretion over our stand-alone Shire numbers by 2020.
This assumes $500m of operational cost savings, $400m of incremental
sales (adding $170m of operating earnings) and a combined Group tax rate
of 16.5% by 2020. We conservatively assume a 20% decline in our prior
stand-alone Baxalta FEIBA forecasts due to the potential impact of ACE-910
in haemophilia A inhibitor patients.

PM

Blue Sky and Grey Sky Scenarios move 2020E EPS by +24% and -20%:
Our Blue Sky valuation scenario encompasses a stronger lifitegrast launch,
increased overall revenues to reach the company's

$20bn objective by

2020, an incremental $250m of cost savings from the deal and full pipeline
success. This boosts '15-'20 CAGR EPS growth from 13% to 18%. Our Grey
Sky scenario models FEIBA and Adynovate eroding faster, the ADHD
franchise slowing and no pipeline success. This reduces '15-'20 CAGR EPS
growth to 8%.

PM

Sorry for the formatting

11:32 am
PM

Shire Baxalta combination offers best in class EPS growth at an
attractive valuation: Shire is well placed to use the ex-US infrastructure
from Baxalta to accelerate the commercialization of the groups rare disease
drugs and is broadening the portfolio away from ADHD. Baxalta adds a
number of new areas with attractive growth and high barriers to entry.
■ Catalysts: Update on synergies post deal close (3 June). 2H16: P2 data for
SHP607 in retinopathy of prematurity (40% POS, peak $350m) and SHP610
in San Fillipo (20% POS, peak $600m). lifitegrast PDUFA 22 July 2016.
■ Valuation: Shire trades on a 2018 PE of 10.5x vs a peer group average of
15.4x (EU Majors 15.7x) and on an EV/NPV of 1.22 against a peer group
average of 1.10 (EU Majors 1.02, US/International 1.15).

BE

Here's Morgan Stanley.

11:40 am
BE

- Halfords issued an FY Q4 trading update, two weeks after the end of its
financial year, in which it guided that full year Pre Tax Profits were likely to be
in the range of £78-82m. The outcome today (£81.5m) is unlikely to surprise
anyone (consensus was looking for £80m).
- Although this profit outcome is likely to be dismissed as being 'in line', we
think it worth stepping back and reflecting on the fact that, despite a very
favourable macro-economic backdrop through most of 2015, profits are flat
on the prior year. More worryingly, they are more than 30% lower than those
reported five years ago. We think this reflects growing structural pressures on
the Halfords proposition.

BE

- The strategy update is lengthy but looks pretty routine to us. CEO Jill
McDonald joined the group in May 2015 and set out her "Moving into Gear"
strategy at the Interims back in November. At first sight, the strategy section in
today's statement appears to be primarily an update on progress on the plan
announced then.
- As previously indicated, however, the company has today given new
guidance on its preferred capital structure. Going forwards the company will
be targeting net debt of 1.0x EBITDA. Although the company finished the year
with net debt of just 0.4x EBITDA, the subsequent acquisition of Tredz and
Wheelies (for a combined initial cash consideration of £18m) means that there
is no special dividend or share buyback announced today, which may
disappoint some.

BE

- The financial guidance for the year ahead looks to be less detailed than that
provided historically by the previous management team. The company has
reiterated its previous guidance that it expects Pre Tax Profit in FY 2016/17 to
be "broadly unchanged" from that reported in FY 2015/16, though has made
clear that the previous guidance was made on the basis of a £:$ exchange rate
of 1:1.50 and quantified that a move to 1:1.45 would reduce profits by around
£3m.
- We have yet to speak with the company this morning, but based on the
above guidance, we think it likely that consensus earnings forecasts for FY
2016/17 will fall modestly (c2%) today. Prior to today consensus was looking
for Pre Tax Profits of £80.5m (EPS 33.0p).

11:41 am
BE

- Based on existing consensus forecasts and last night's closing price, Halfords
is trading on 13.5x Cal 2016 earnings, 7.9x EBITDA with a 3.9% dividend yield.
This compares with a UK General Retail sector trading on 15.0x. 8.8x and 3.14
respectively.

BE

And Canaccord.

BE

Halfords delivered a 0.5% increase in FY16 PBT - vs the 52-week pro forma FY15 – to
£81.5m, compared with company-compiled consensus of £79.7m (CGe: £79.0m). This
put it at the upper end of the guidance range of £78m - £82m, which was reiterated at
the Q4 pre-close in mid-April. The key drivers of this performance were the gross margin
(down 30bps) coming in at the top end of guidance and operating costs, where bonus
accrual savings and other cost savings initiatives held the annual increase to just 1%.
The company has declared a full-year dividend of 17.0p, an increase of 3%, which is
slightly ahead of the consensus forecast of 16.8p (CGe: 17.0p). Year-end net debt fell
£14m to £47.9m, compared with consensus of £49.5m. The net debt to EBITDA ratio fell
further to 0.4x from 0.6x last year. The company has announced a new net debt/EBITDA
target of 1.0x, to move to "over time", which could stretch to 1.5x for an appropriate
acquisition. This figure obviously excludes the initial £18.4m consideration for the
acquisition of Tredz and Wheelies, announced last week.

11:43 am
BE

However, no return was announced today, which could disappoint in some quarters. On
FY16's metrics, at 1.0x net debt/EBITDA, there was some £67m of headroom, equivalent
to 34p per share (or 25p per share including the initial consideration for the recent
acquisition).
Financial guidance is largely unchanged, with the small wrinkle of the adverse impact
of the dollar rate, which will likely see a small net reduction of c £1m to consensus FY17
PBT of £80.5m (CGe: £79.5m) after allowing for c £1m enhancement from the recent
acquisition.In terms of divisional performance, the core Retail division saw EBIT fall
back 1.1% to £81.8m (vs £82.7m last year), compared with consensus of £79.9m (CGe:
£79.2m). LFL sales increased 1.3%, with gross margin down 30bps and operating costs
up 1%. As a result, the operating margin fell back 20bps to 9.4%. Autocentres had a
solid year with LFL sale growth of 2.5% and total sales growth of 4.1%. EBITDA rose
13.2%, meeting the "low double-digit %" growth anticipated at this stage last year, while
EBIT was flat at £3.8m (consensus of £3.9m), due to depreciation continuing to rise as a
result of ongoing capital investments.

BE

Impact on our view
The shares have recovered strongly since January (+40%) on the back of two solid
quarters of trading, including positive LFLs from Cycling after the disappointing Q2 set
back. This in turn has underpinned confidence in the group's cash generation and de-
leveraging, raising hopes of special returns of surplus cash to shareholders, even though
these remain the fourth priority in the pecking order of capital prioritisation (behind
growth capex, the ordinary dividend, and "appropriate M&A opportunities").
Valuation
The shares are trading on a cal 16 PER of 13.3x, moving to 12.9x for cal 17. The EV/
EBITDA valuation stands at 7.6x for cal 16 and 7.1x for cal 17. The shares have seen their
discount to the wider sector narrow considerably, now standing at 10%, having been
above 35% earlier this year. The shares yield around 4%.

PM

75% by principal amount) of each of the Company's Notes and Bonds.

Whilst the Standstill Agreement remains in effect, the Company does not intend to make the April 2016 Coupon Payments. The continuing failure to make those payments constitutes an Event of Default under the Bonds and Notes, respectively. At a time when an Event of Default subsists the holders of not less than one-quarter of the principal amount of the Notes or the Bonds, as the case may be, then outstanding may request the relevant Trustee to declare the principal amount of the Notes or the Bonds, as the case may be, immediately due and payable.

BE

The slowdown of the discounters excites Barclays.

BE

UK Food Retail

Slowest discounter growth since 2011

Key numbers (on a four-week basis):

· Tesco: -21bps (vs -41bps last time)

· Sainsbury: -29bps (vs -27bps last time)

· Morrison: -35bps (vs -13bps last time)

· ASDA: -72bps (vs -80bps last time)

· Aldi & Lidl: +82bps (vs +100bps last time)

First impressions:

· Overall Tesco, Sainsbury and ASDA all did better than what we would have mechanically expected, with Morrison the only one that seemed a bit weaker than expected.

· From an industry perspective, growth was +1.1% yoy in the four weeks ending 22 May, up strongly from -1.8% last time (which however was distorted by the earlier date of Easter in 2016) – on a 12-week rolling view growth improved modestly, to +0.2% from -0.1% last time.

· Kantar Worldpanel mentions that grocery deflation was -1.5% in the 12-week period, the same as the last two periods.

· Tesco’s sales growth turned positive in the four-week period (+0.1%), and its 21bps of share loss looks particularly better given a very tough basis of comparison from last year.

· Sainsbury’s 29bps of share loss also came out slightly better than expectations. Kantar commented that its recent share losses have been driven by a decline in pack sales, which is the short-term result of shifting its promotional emphasis from multi-pack deals to straightforward price cuts.

· ASDA continued to lose the largest market share among the big four with a -4.8% sales decline, which is however also modestly better than what we could have mechanically expected.

· Morrison appears to be the relative loser in terms of market share (-35bps) given flat comps from last year, although its sales numbers continued to be affected by store disposals (Kantar share data relates to total sales growth).

· Co-op continued its recent strong run, posting positive sales growth of 2.9% and share gain of 8bps.

· The discounters collectively gained 84bps of market share yoy - on a 12-week basis, its sales growth of 12.6% is even the lowest since February 2011. Kantar highlighted the premiumisation trend at both banners, with Aldi’s premium own label Specially Selected growing by 15% while Lidl’s Deluxe range growing by an impressive 65%.

BE

The UK remains the most deflationary market in Europe. Deflation was -
1.5% YoY over the last 12 wks, stable vs. the previous run-rate. As can be seen
in Exhibit 19, the UK market has been deflationary since October 2014, after
having been one of the most inflationary markets in Europe in the 5 years
prior. Given the current price gap between the Big 4 and hard discounters, we
expect the market to remain deflationary in the forseeable future.

BE

Polarisation remains acute: Discounters Aldi/Lidl sales slowed down this
month (+13% y-o-y), but their market share gains remained elevated as they
accounted for a larger share of the market: in May, they gained 120 bps of
market share combined (to 10.5%). This compares with a gain of 150 bps on a
trailing 12 month basis. Aldi and Lidl sales growth was largely driven by an
increase in the share of wallet (with premium own label lines booming), rather
than gains in traffic away from the Big 4. At the high-end of the market, both
M&S and Waitrose accelerated their market gains in May: while the market
grew +1.1% y-o-y, M&S food sales grew +7.0% and Waitrose grew +3.5%.

BE

Asda: from bad to worse. Asda again underperformed the rest of the market,
by 540bps this period, one of the worst monthly performances over the past
12 years of Kantar records. This suggests Asda is on course to post a quarterly
decline in LFLs of 6% to 7% in 2Q. If correct, this would be the worst quarterly
LFL sales decline in over 50 years (in 1Q16, Walmart reported a LFL sales
decline of -5.7% at Asda). Our latest UK AlphaWise Price Tracker suggests
that Asda still has not moved on prices YTD, despite the company's comments.

11:56 am
BE

Kantar data suggest Tesco stabilizing, Morrisons and Sainsbury under
pressure. Tesco lost less market share in May (-10 bps) than at any point over
the past 12 months (-60 bps on average). Kantar data implies more or less flat
LFL sales in 1Q for Tesco (ending 28 May), in line with our current forecasts.
Morrison, the retailer with the highest overlap with Asda, conceded 363bps to
the market this period (vs. -134bps in P4), a performance partially driven by
store closures (impacting sales by ~2.8% this month vs. ~2.5% for the
previous month). Kantar data only has 3 weeks of overlap with Morrison's Q2
17e and Kantar data suggests LFLs have stood at c.+0.4%, in line with our
+0.4% estimate. According to Kantar, Sainsbury's sales performance was
relatively poor in P5, with the chain losing -30 bps market share in May (vs. flat
on a trailing 12 month basis). This was likely driven by Sainsbury shifting away
from multi pack deals. To a lesser extent, the Co-op accelerating its market
share gain in the convenience channel (see Exhibit 17), might be a factor
explaining Sainsbury's underperformance.

PM

Mexican Lithium Nearing Launch Pad
Advancing a Potentially World-Class Lithium Project

Bacanora’s Sonora lithium project in Mexico has the potential to become a world-class lithium mine, with production 35ktpa of lithium carbonate in the bottom quartile of the cost curve for use in the rapidly growing lithium battery market. Sonora’s total resources exceed 8Mt of lithium carbonate equivalent, amongst the largest deposits in the world. A bankable feasibility study in Q1 calendar 2017 is the major upcoming catalyst to move the project to a construction decision. Our base case model, which assumes higher operating costs, lower production and lower realized pricing, reflecting execution risk and the company’s unique production method, still suggests at least 20% upside from the current share price. Our upside scenario, assuming the project can hit its targets, suggests nearly 100% upside. In the short term, we think progress in arranging offtake related financing is a key catalyst for the shares.

PM

Lithium Market: Bullish on an 18-month view

Based on our detailed supply/demand analysis (see our proprietary lithium market report here ), we believe that having gone into deficit last year the market will remain tight through 2016 and 2017, despite more supply coming from Australia and Argentina. As a result we are bullish lithium on an 18-month view, with an average price target of $8,250/t for 2017. This annual average represents 16% upside from current spot, but on a shorter-term basis, overshooting into the mid-to-high $8,000s per tonne looks likely.

Significant Hurdles Remains

The timing of Sonora’s initial production, expected by early calendar year 2019, could be challenging. While we continue to view the lithium market favourably, the sheer number and potential volume of new projects could catch up to demand growth by the end of the decade. Further, the deposit geology and process plant are relatively unique, and considerable work remains to prove the economics of the project. The completion of the BFS by Q1 calendar 2017 is an important de-risking event in this regard.

12:00 pm
PM

Initiate With Outperform Rating, The Race is On

We initiate coverage of Bacanora with an Outperform rating, and £1.20/sh target. Our target is based on a 0.75x multiple to our NAV at an 8% discount rate (which includes a 40% risk-weighting on the company’s phase 2 expansion of the Sonora project post 2021E). Our de-risked long-term NAV/sh is £2.56/sh, more than 150% above the current share price. Over the next two years, Bacanora is in a critical phase – it must successfully demonstrate the technical recoverability of lithium carbonate at Sonora, the economic feasibility of the project, arrange an offtake agreement, and secure project financing, no small task for a junior development company. But given the project’s large scale, expandability, close proximity to key markets in the US and Asia, and potentially low cost structure, we think the company is in a solid position to execute on these plans.
